customer_name: S C DEPARTMENT OF PARKS REC & TOURISM

citations.narrative:
Over the course of three months, The facility lost six birds in their Shorebird Aviary due to the breaching of the aviary’s
fenceline. Between the dates of June 17th – September 24th, 2024, a total of five gulls were reported missing by the staff,
and the remains of one deceased Blue Heron was found within the exhibit. After each occurrence, a thorough inspection
of the aviary's perimeter was performed, with traps and game cameras setup within the habitat, and arborists hired to
inspect the habitat’s canopy. As a result, the facility captured and removed raccoons and opossums from the traps within
the habitat; and patched the holes identified along the marsh side of the exhibit and canopy of the exhibit.
Ongoing threats due to predation, or openings made that can allow for escape, are a concern for all birds housed in their
respective enclosures, as these opportunities increase the risks of predation, injuries, escape, and distress for all of the
birds on-hand.
The facility must ensure that bird enclosures are maintained in good repair, protect the birds from injury, contain the birds,
and restrict other animals from entering that may negatively affect the welfare of the birds within.
Corrective actions were promptly taken by the facility following each occurrence.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representatives.
n

narrative:
3.150(a)  Critical
   
Facilities, general. 
Over the course of three months, The facility lost six birds in their Shorebird Aviary due to the breaching of the aviary’s 
fenceline. Between the dates of June 17th – September 24th, 2024, a total of five gulls were reported missing by the staff, 
and the remains of one deceased Blue Heron was found within the exhibit. After each occurrence, a thorough inspection 
of the aviary's perimeter was performed, with traps and game cameras setup within the habitat, and arborists hired to 
inspect the habitat’s canopy. As a result, the facility captured and removed raccoons and opossums from the traps within 
the habitat; and patched the holes identified along the marsh side of the exhibit and canopy of the exhibit. 
Ongoing threats due to predation, or openings made that can allow for escape, are a concern for all birds housed in their 
respective enclosures, as these opportunities increase the risks of predation, injuries, escape, and distress for all of the 
birds on-hand. 
The facility must ensure that bird enclosures are maintained in good repair, protect the birds from injury, contain the birds, 
and restrict other animals from entering that may negatively affect the welfare of the birds within.  
Corrective actions were promptly taken by the facility following each occurrence. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representatives.
